title: How Can Trance States Impact Symptomatology in Hypnotherapy?
first_phrase: This text explores the concept of trance states in hypnotherapy, and how they can both evoke resources and create symptomatology. The author discusses the importance of working with the trance state of the individual to deconstruct it, rather than inducing another kind of trance that may not be pivotal to the patient's symptoms. The author draws on the work of Milton Erickson, who promoted the idea of trance states as a natural occurrence in daily life. In the last 200 tokens, the author discusses Erickson's perspective on inducing satisfactory trance states in hypnotic work.

last_phrase: In conclusion, the therapeutic approach to hypnosis and trance states should involve working with the person's existing trance state rather than attempting to induce a new one. Erickson's approach revolutionized the classical view of trance and highlighted the importance of the presentation of indirect or direct techniques to induce and maintain a satisfactory level of trance. It is essential to recognize that inducing trance is one process and trance utilization is another, requiring skilled work and full regard for the individual's capacities to learn and respond.
